We shall conclude, That although these wicked councellours about His Majestie, have presumed under His Majesties Name, to put that dishonour and affront upon both Houses of Parliament, as to make them the countenancers of Treason, enough to have dissolved all the bonds and sinewes of mutuall confidence betwixt His Majestie and His Parliament (of whom the Maxime of the Law is, that a dishonourable thing ought not to bee imagined of them) yet we doubt not, but it shall in the end appear before all the World, that our endeavours have beene most hearty and sincere for the Maintenance of the true Protestant Religion, the Kings Just Perogative, the Lawes and Liberties of the Land, and the Priviledges of Parliament, In which endeavours by the grace of God we will still persist, though we should perish in the work, which if it should be, it is much to bee feared; That, Religion, Lawes, Liberties, and Parliaments, would not be long-lived after us.

Pag. 307. Your Majesties most humble and faithfull Subjects having nothing in their thoughts & desires, more precious and of higher esteeme (next to the immediate Honour and Service of God) then
the just and faithfull performance of their duety to your Majesty and this Kingdome, &c.

Whereas pag. 282. The King alleadgeth some speaches in the Houses to the prejudice of the Royall Branches, The Parliament fully answereth pag. 696. this, and although they would perswade His Majesty, that there is little confidence to bee placed in our modesty and duety; Yet as God is witnesse of our thoughts, so shall our actions, witnesse to all the World, That to the honour of Religion, and of those that are most zealous in it (so much stricken at by the contrivers of that Declaration under odious names) wee shall suffer more from, and for our Soveraign, then we hope, God will ever permit the malice of wicked Councellors to put us to. And though the happinesse of this and all Kingdomes dependeth chiefly upon God, yet wee acknowledge, that it doth so mainly depend upon His Majesty, and the Royall Branches of that Root, That as we have heretofore, so we shall hereafter esteeme no Hazard too great, no reproach too vile, but that we shall willingly goe through the one, and undergoe the other; That we and the whole Kingdome may enjoy that happinesse, which we cannot in an Ordinary way of providence expect from any other Fountaine, or Streames then those from whence (were the poison of evill Councell once removed from about them) wee doubt not but wee and the whole Kingdome should bee satisfied most aboundantly.

Pag. 728. We never suffered that word of deposing the King to goe out of our mouths, nor the thing to enter in our thoughts, nor can it be collected out of any thing we have said. And now for the Propositions wherewith we are said to assault His Majestie, and endeavour to divest Him of all his Royall rights and dignities; We doubt not but we shall make it appear to all the World that what may seeme highest in our Propositions, hath beene in effect asked and obtained by our Predecessours before us, and by our Nieghbours beside us, and that we have more reason to ask it and to obtaine it, then either the one or the other, and yet to testifie to all the World how much wee desire peace, and to avoid the miseries and confusion of a civill Warre, wee have not, nor shall insist upon any thing, but what we hold necessary for preservation of the safety and peace of the Kingdome, and for the securitie of our Religion and Liberties, and these good Lawes which we already have, and hope farther to obtaine by the frequent meeting and free sitting of Parliaments: And as we have bin careful to decline all appearance of any private respects in them to our selves; So wee having the Honour of God, and of His Majesty, and the Peace, Freedome and Prosperity of this Kingdome, chiefly before our eyes in these our Propositions and in all our actions, we rest assured, that both God and Man will abhor and abominate that monstruous and most injurious charge laid upon the representative body of this Kingdom, of designing the ruine not only of his Majesties person, but of Monarchie it self. And we appeal to all the World, whether worse words then these can bee given? And whether wee may not justly expect the
worst actions that the malice and power of the Malignant Party about His Majesty can produce.

Pag. 750. GOD who sees our innocency, and that we have no aimes, but at his glory, and the publike good, will (we hope) free your Majesty from these destructive Councells, who labour to maintaine their own power by Blood and Rapine: And blesse our endeavour, who seek nothing but to procure and establish the Honourable Peace and safety of your Majestie and Kingdomes, upon the sure foundation of Religion and Justice.

The Declarations after mentioned were sent from the Parliament of England to the Kingdome of Scotland, to inform them of the true state of the quarrell and cause of the war, and to perswade them to ingage with them therein, which they did accordingly.

The King by His Letter of the 20 of May, 1642. to the Councell of Scotland, declared His great sufferings from His Parliament, and that Hee was only maintaining His Authority, &c. as is inserted in the pag. 255. Thereupon the Parliament emitts a Declaration, and sends it to Scotland, assuring them by Protestation, that His Majesties sufferings come not from any intention or action of theirs, who endeavour with all fidelity to procure the happinesse of His Majestie and of His Kingdome: And that they should doe their best endeavours to promote the Honour, Wealth, and Prosperity of Scotland (because of our great affection and respect to them at that time, upon believing their Declarations) and preserve their Union, &c.
_____
pag. 330.

In August 1643. The Parliament sends down Colonel Pickering to the Generall Assembly, with a Declaration to them, shewing, that they thought fit to send them a coppy of their Supplication to His Majestie, (wherewith hee brought also other Declarations, and gave them to the Lords of the Secret Counsell, and Conservators of Peace) That, that Church and Kingdome (whereunto they are tied by so many and so neer bonds, both civil and spirituall) may see that the like mind is now in them, that formerly appeared to be in the Nation; and that they were tender of bloud, and zealous for a reformation of Church and State, which if not interrupted by war, they would settle, to the encrease of His Majesties Honour and State, the peace and prosperity of this Kingdome; and especially to the glory of God, by the advancement of the true Religion, and such a reformation of the Church, as shall bee most agreeable to Gods Word: Out of all which there will also result a most firm and stable Union betweene the two Kingdomes, which according to our Protestation we shall by all good wayes and means, upon all occasions, labour to preserve and maintain.

The Supplication which hee brought, was that which was sent after nomination of my Lord Essex Generall, pag. 465. having that expression, That Hee would return to His Parliament, and hearken to their faithfull Advices, and humble Petitions, which should only bee for advancing Religion, His own Royall Honour and Safety, the
preservation of our Lawes and Liberties; and they should punish and prevent all tumultuous and seditious actions, speeches and writings, which might give him any just cause of distance, or apprehension of danger, from which publike aimes and resolutions, no sinister or privat respect shall ever make them decline; That they should settle the Militia by a Bill, in such a way as shall bee honourable and safe for His Majestie, most agreeable to the duety of Parliament, and effectuall for the good of the Kingdome, that the security thereof bee not for its destruction; with which if His Majesties Counsels and Courses shall concur, we doubt not but we shall quickly make it appear to the world, by the most eminent effects of love and duety, That His Majesties Personal safety, Royall Honour and Greatnes are much dearer to us then our lives and fortunes, which wee do most heartily dedicate, and shall most willingly imploy, for the support and maintenance thereof. They again repeat the same, pag. 509. as the firm and constant resolution, to witnesse their unshaken and constant loyalty; and that they would make Him and His Posterity as much beloved at home, and feared abroad, as any Prince that ever swayed this Scepter.

They renew and enlarge the same in their Petition, the 11. of September, pag. 587. and offers to His Majestie, security, honour, service, obedience, support, and other effects of an humble, loyall, and faithfull Subjection; and seek nothing, but that our Religion, Liberty, Peace of the Kingdome, and Safety of the Parliament may bee secured from the open violence and cunning practises of the wicked party; and as wee never gave Your Majestie any just cause of withdrawing Your Self from Your Great Councell, so it hath ever been, and shall ever be far from us, to give any impediment to Your Majesties returne, or to neglect any proper meanes of curing the distempers of the Kingdome, and closing the dangerous breaches betwixt Your Majesty and Your Parliament, according to the great trust which lyes upon us; And if Your Majesty shall now be pleased to come back to your Parliament without your forces, we shall be ready to secure Your Royall Person, Crowne and Dignity with our lives and fortunes, Your Presence in this great Councell, being the only meanes of any Treaty betwixt Your Majesty and them, with hope of successe.

And in none of our desires to Your Majesty shall we be swayed by any particular mans advantage, but shall give a cleare testimony to Your Majestie and the whole World, That in all things done by us, we faithfully intend the good of Your Majesty, and of Your Kingdomes, and that we will not bee delivered from this end, by any private or selfe respects whatsoever.

Againe they renew the same, pag. 618. Shewing that they have for the just and necessary defence for the Protestant Religion, of Your Majesties Person, Crown and Dignity, of the Lawes, and Liberties of this Kingdome, and the Priviledges and Power of Parliament; Taken up Armes and appointed and authorized Robert Earle
of Essex to bee Captaine Generall, wherein if Your Majestie please to yeeld to our most humble and earnest desires, We do in the presence of Almighty God professe, that we wil receive Your Majestie with all Honour, yeeld you all due obedience and subjection, and faithfullie endeavour to secure Your Person and Estate from all dangers, and to the uttermost of our power, to procure and establish to Your Selfe and Your People, all the blessings of a glorious and happie Reigne.

He delivered also the Votes of the 12 of July, pag. 457. of raising an Army for the safety of the Kings Person, defence of the Parliament, and preserving Religion, Lawes, Lives, and Peace of the Kingdom, and to die and live with the Earle of Essex in that Cause, and the former Petition appointed to be framed.

He delivered likewise the Declarations, pag. 458. wherein the Parliament expresseth, that in all their endeavours, they intend wholly the advancement of His Majesties Honour and Safety, And the regainment of the ancient (though of late yeares much invaded) Rights, Lawes, and Liberties, being the Birth-right of the Subjects of this Land, and settling of the true Protestant Religion (the glory of their Nation) in Peace and Purity.

He delivered the Declaration, pag. 461. concerning the distractions of the Kingdome (wherein the King breaking his Declarations is challenged) they desire all mens assistance in this necessary defensive Warre, And that they shall in all their proceedings manifest, they are carryed by no respects but of the publike good; That alteration of Religion is the maine end of their Enemies, which will draw on losse of Liberty, and subversion of Law; so it rests only, Whether freeborn English-men will adhere to King and Parliament, or to the King seduced by Jesuites and Cavaliers.

In their reply to the King, pag. 473. they shew the reason why they tooke into their custody the Town of Hull, the Magazine and Navy, passed the Ordinance of the Militia, and made preparation of Armies, was for the security of Religion, the safety of His Majesties Person, of the Kingdome and Parliament, all which they did see in evident and imminent danger, from which when they shall bee secured, and that the forces of the Kingdome shall not bee used to the destruction thereof, They shall then bee ready to withdraw the Garison out of Hull, to deliver the Magazine and Navy, And settle the Militia by Bill, in such a way, as shall be Honourable and Sa fefor His Majestie, most agreeable to the duety of Parliament, and effectuall for the good of the Kingdome, as they have profest in their late Petition: And as for the laying down of Armes, when the causes which moved them to provide for the defence of His Majestie, the Kingdome and Parliament, shall be taken away, they shall very willingly and chearfully forbear any farther preparations, and lay down their force already raised.

He delivered also the Declaration, pag. 491. giving an accompt to the World of the Justice of their proceedings, and to warne them all
to concurre, They complain, that the designe of their Enemies is, to alter the constitution and frame of this Government both in Church and State: That they begunne with Scotland by the Service Book; For well they knew the same fate attended both Kingdomes; And Religion could not be altered in the one, without altering it in the other, and Religion is there called The life of our lives.

And seeing now the Question is so clearly stated: They invite all to assist for the preservation of Religion, the King and our Selves, And that it appeareth that it is neither Hull, nor Magazine, nor Militia, which are grounds of the Warre, whereupon they conclude their accompt to the World, That they the Lords and Commons were resolved to expose their Lives and Fortunes for Maintenance of the true Religion, the Kings Person, Honour and Estate, Priviledges of Parliament, and Right and Liberties of Subjects, and for prevention of alteration of Religion; And requireth all who have sense of Pietie, Honour, or Compasson, to help a distressed State, especially such as have taken the Protestation, and are bound in this same duety with us unto their God, their King and Countrey, to come to their assistance, This being the true Cause for which we raise an Army under the Earle of Essex, with whom wee will live and die in this quarrell. This is sent to Scotland with Colonell Pickering, is read to the Generall Assembly, Lords of Councell, and Conservators of Peace, and beleeved there.

In all the Letters and Declarations from the Conservators of Peace in Scotland, there is a cleare evidence of our earnest pressing Unity in Religion and Peace, with all respect and tendernesse to His Majesties Authority, and the Subjects Liberty. And the Parliament of England the 20. of October 1642. doth answere, that they were willing to concurre in all good wayes for the Kings Honour and Happinesse, and Unity between the Kingdomes: And generally in all Declarations of the Houses sent to Scotland, They expresse their desire for uniformity, and preservation of His Majesties Authority.

Pag. 663. The Declaration and Protestation of the Lords and Commons to this Kingdom, and to the whole World, October 22. 1642. We, in presence of Almighty God, for the satisfaction of our consciences, and the discharge of our great trust, protest and declare, That no private passion or respect, or evill intention to His Majesties Person, no designe to the prejudice of his just Honour and Authority, engaged us to take Armes and raise Forces, And wee have alwayes desired from our Soules, manifested in our Proceedings, Petitions, and Remonstrances to His Majesty, professed our loyaltie and obedience to his Crowne, readinesse and resolution to defend his Person and support his Estate, with our lives and fortunes to the uttermost of our power.

They remember a petition sent, pag. 587. Wherein they professe in the sight of Almighty God, which is the strongest obligation that any Christian, and the most solemne publike Faith, which any such State as a Parliament can give: That we would receive him with all
Honour, yeeld him all true obedience and subjection, and defend his Person and Estate; That in this cause and defence thereof, they expect the concurrence of Scotland, according to the Act of Pacification: And which safety of Religion, Lawes, and Liberties, We do here againe professe before the everliving God, to be the chief end of all our Councells, and Resolutions, without any intention or desire to hurt or injure his Majesty, either in his Person or just Power. This Declaration was sent to the Conservators of Peace, with their safe conduct, and delivered by Colonell Pickering unto them.

In the Declaration to the World, pag. 657. sent to Scotland concerning the allegations, That the Army is raised to murther or depose the King; wee hoped any that professed the name of a Christian, could not have so little Charity as to raise such a scandall, especially when they must needs know the Protestation taken by every member of both Houses, whereby they promise in presence of Almighty GOD, to defend His Majesties Person: The Promise and Protestation made by the members of both Houses, upon the nomination of the Generall to live and die with him, wherein is expressed, That this Army was raised for the defence of the Kings Person; Our earnest addresses and humble petitions to His Majesty, to remove his Royall Person from that Army, A request inconsistent with any purpose to offer the least violence to his Person, which hath and ever shall be dear unto us: That their Religion and Liberties being secured unto them, they shall willingly disband. To the imputation of their intention to change the Government, they answere, That the Army is raised for the Lands necessary preservation.

The Declaration to the Estates of Holland, pag. 635. declareth the question betweene the King and Parliament, Is not whether Hee shall enjoy the same Prerogative and Power, which hath belonged to our former Kings, His Royall Predecessors; But whether that Prerogative and Power shall bee used to our defence or ruine, and we expect nothing from Him but security and protection from those mischievouous designes multiplied against them.

But above all, remember the Declaration, 7. November, pag. 737. directed and sent to the Kingdome of Scotland, and delivered to that State by Colonel Pickering, mentioning, that Scotland had lovingly invited them to a neerer and higher degree of Union, in matters of Religion, and Church Government, which we have most willingly and affectually embraced, and intend to pursue: And though we seek nothing from his Majestie, that may diminish his just authority or honour, and have by many humble Petitions endeavoured to put an end to this unnaturall war and combustion, and to procure His protection and security, for our Religion, Liberties and Persons (according to that great trust His Majestie is bound to by the Lawes of the Land) and shall continue to renew our Petitions in that kinde, wee are necessitated to stand upon our just defence, and to seek the speedy and powerfull assiance of our Brethren, according to the Act of Pacification, common duety of Christianity, and particular
Interest of their own Nation, which would produce preservation of Religion, Honour, Safety, and Peace to His Majestie and Subjects, and a more strict conjunction of the Councels, Designes, and Endeavours of both Nations, for the relief of the reformed Churches: All which we did believe, and desire to see observed, and did not believe the Kings Answer thereunto, immediatly sent to Scotland against them, as intending to countenance Sects and Schismes, and to subvert His Royall Authority.
Wee could cite to your Lordships as many of our Declarations to the same sense, which wee acknowledge as obligatory, and so need not to repeat them.
But that which sticks most with us, are the Oaths taken, first separatim by both these Nations, and then conjunctim in the last solemn League and Covenant between the Kingdoms.

Wee need neither set down our first Covenant, nor the Protestation which is so short, cleer, and known to all, viz. To defend and maintain, according to the duety of my Alleagance, His Majesties Royall Person, Honour, and State, &c. and in all just and honourable wayes, to preserve the Union and Peace between the Kingdoms, and neither for hope, fear, or other respect relinquish the promise, vow, and Protestation, which whosoever would not take, was voted to be unfit to bear office in Church or State, whereunto our Oath of Parliament is paralell almost in iisdem verbis.

Concerning the late solemn League and Covenant, wee may not forget the Act of the Generall Assembly of Scotland, and of the Convention of Estates, 17 August, 1643. approving of the first draught of it, as the most powerfull mean, by the blessing of God, for settling and preserving the true Protestant Religion, with perfect Peace in His Majesties Dominions, and propagating the same to other Nations, and for establishing his Maiesties Throne to all Ages and Generations, and recommending it in these termes to the Kingdome of England; and which is most fully twise or thrise expressed in their Declaration, then sent to the Houses, and in their Answer to the Divines.

Like as the two Acts of the Commissioners of the Assembly, and Committee of Estates, in October, 1643. approving the same (after the return therof from England) in the same terms, and appoint it so to be sworn and subscribed: Whereupon the Covenant having these Acts prefixed, was subscribed and sworn in a most solemn manner by the Commissioners of both Kingdoms, at Edinburgh, and one Principall so subscribed, Delivered by us to the English Commissioners, and another from them to us, to be keeped in retentis.
Likewise the Ordinance of the Honourable Houses, for the subscribing of the Covenant, prefixed an Exhortation, and therein affirmeth.

For what is there almost in this Covenant, which was not for substance either expressed, or manifestly included in that solemn Protestation
of May 5. 1641. wherein the whole Kingdome stands ingaged untill this day: The sinfull neglect whereof doth (as we may justly fear) open a Floud-gate, the more to let in all these calamities upon the Kingdome, and cast upon it a necessity of renewing Covenant, and of entring into this.

If it bee pleaded, That this Covenant crosseth the Oathes of Supremacy and Alleageance, there can be nothing further from Truth; for this Covenant binds all, and more strongly engageth them to preserve and defend the Kings Majesties Person and Authority, in the Preservation and Defence of the true Religion, and Liberties of the Kingdomes.

The Covenant it self, both in the Title and in the Preamble, setteth downe the three mayn Motives, Dueties, and Ends thereof, whereof the second is the Honour and Happinesse of the King and His Posterity.

In the third Article, wee shall with the same sincerity, reality, and constancy in our severall vocations, endeavour with our Estates and Lives, mutually to preserve the Rights and Priviledges of the Parliaments and the Liberties of the Kingdomes, And to preserve and defend the Kings Majesties Person and Authority, in the preservation and defence of the true Religion and Liberties of the Kingdomes. That the world may bear witnesse with our consciences of our loyalty, and that we have no thoughts or intentions to diminish His Majesties just Power and Greatnesse.

In the fourth, we shall discover evill instruments, by hindering the reformation of Religion, dividing the King from his people, or one of the Kingdomes from another, or making any parties among the people contrary to this League and Covenant.

In the fifth, And whereas the happines of a blessed peace between these Kingdomes, Denied in former times to our Progenitors, is by the good providence of God granted unto us, and hath beene lately concluded and settled by both Parliaments; Wee shall each one of us according to our power and interest, indeavour that they may remaine conjoyned in a firme Peace and Union to all posterity, And that justice may be done upon the wilfull opposers thereof, in manner expressed in the precedent Articles.

Now this firm Union between them settled by both Parliaments, and to bee continued by that Article; as also by the Protestation before mentioned, and our Oath of Parliament, is expressed in the Act of Pacification in the large Treaty, in his verbis, That the great blesing of a constant and friendly Conjunction of the two Kingdomes, now united by Alleageance and loyall Subjection, to one Soveraigne and Head, may be firmly observed, and continued to all posterity.

In the sixth Article wee may not make defection to the contrary part, or give our selves to a detestable indifferency or neutrality in this cause, which so much concerneth the Glory of God, good of the Kingdomes, and Honour of the King, but all our dayes zealously
and constantly promote it against all opposition and impediments; all which we shall do as in the fight of God, and perform all Dueties we owe to God and man, and make this Covenant in the presence of Almighty God the Searcher of all hearts, with a true intention to perform the same, as we shall answer at the great Day.

Wee cannot but remember the first Article of the Treaty between the Kingdomes, viz. It is agreed and concluded, that the Covenant represented to the Convention of Estates, and Generall Assembly of Scotland, and sent to both Houses of the Parliament of England, in the same form as it is now returned from the two Houses of the Parliament of England to their Brethren of Scotland, and allowed by the Committee of Estates, and Committee of the Generall Assembly, be sworn and subscribed by both Kingdoms, as a most neer tye and conjunction betwixt them, for their mutuall defence against the Papist and Prelaticall Faction, and their Adherents in both Kingdomes, and for pursuance of the ends exprest in the Covenant; and that the rest of the Articles are expresly conceived to be in pursuance of the ends exprest in the said Covenant. And the eighth Article, That no Cessation, nor any Pacification or Agreement for Peace whatsoever, shall bee made for either Kingdome, or their Armes, without the mutuall Advice or Consent of both Kingdomes, or their Committees (by vertue whereof wee debated these Propositions with your Lordships) is in pursuance of the same ends. And the ninth Article containeth the publike Faith of the Kingdome of Scotland, That neither our entrance into, nor continuance in the Kingdome of England shall bee made use of (wee hope no more by others then by us) to any other ends then are expressed in the Covenant and Articles of this Treaty; And that all matters of Difference shall bee determined by the mutuall Advice and Consent of both Kingdomes, or their Committees: upon the Covenant and Treaty, the Kingdome of Scotland sending in their Army for your Assistance, emitted to the world a Declaration of their Intentions in that war, shewing their three Motives, three Dueties, and three Ends, conform to the Covenant, and planting it as their Motto on all their Banners and Colours, Covenant for Religion, Crown, and Kingdomes, inserting it in their Commission to the Lord General, their Directions through the Counties, and Articles of War, and the Military Oath taken by all the Army; Desiring no otherwise a Blessing upon their Endeavours, then as they shall bee directed to the pursuance of their Ends, inserted in the Title of the Covenant, assuring that the War is not against His Majestie, but that the Wicked being removed, a good understanding may bee established betwixt His Majestie and His People, remembring our publike Faith, given in the ninth of April; And assuring, that their pious, loyall, and faithfull Desires being obtained, wee should most willingly return, esteeming it our greatest Happinesse, that Truth with Peace be established in all His Majesties Dominions.

As wee a part, so both the Kingdomes together joyned in Arms emitted their joint publike Declaration to the world to the same effect; and with many the like Expressions, founding the War on the Covenant, calling it The Cause and Quarrell of God, and ending with a notable Close, viz. Wee have after long and grave Consultation resolved and decreed never to lay down Arms, till Truth and Peace by the Blessing of GOD bee settled in this Island upon a firm foundation, for the present and future Generations, which shall bee esteemed of us an abundant reward of all that wee can doe or suffer in this Cause.

div.head: Concerning Ʋniformity in Religion.
div.p: IN August 1642. The Parliament sends down Colonel Pickering to the General Assembly with a Declaration to them, shewing they thought fit to send them a Copie of their Supplication to his Majestie, wherewith he brought also other Declarations, and gave them to the Lords of Secret Councel and Conservers of Peace, that that Church and Kingdom (whereunto they are tied by so many and so neer bonds both Civil and Spirituall) may see that the like minde is now in them, that formerly appeared to be in that Nation, and that they were tender of blood, and zealous for a Reformation of Church and State, which if not interrupted by War, they would settle to the increase of his Majesties honor and State, the Peace and prosperity of this Kingdom, and specially to the glory of God, by the advancement of the true Religion, and such a Reformation of the Church, as shall be most agreeable to Gods Word: Out of all which there will also most undoubtedly result, a most firm and stable Union betwixt the two Kingdoms, which according to our Protestation we shall by all good means and wayes upon all occasions labour to preserve and maintain.

Pag. 792. In their Declaration giving an account to the world of the Justice of their proceedings, they complain that the designe of their Enemies is to alter the constitution and frame of this Government, both in Church and State: And that when they conceived the way to be sufficiently prepared, They at last resolved to put on their Master-piece in Scotland, in imposing upon them a Popish Service-Book, for well they knew the same fate attended both Kingdoms, and Religion could not be altered in the one without the other. Ibidem. Religion is called the life of their lives.

Pag. 595. The Declaration of the General Assembly of the Kirk of Scotland, sent in an answer to a Declaration from the Parliament of England to them, Sheweth, That the hearts of the godly are grieved, That contrary to their Prayers, and the Professions both of King and Parliament, the Reformation of Religion moveth so slowly, That it ought first of all to be intended and endeavoured, and that when supreame providence giveth opportunity, no other work can prosper, or successe be durable in the hand of his servants, if it be not apprehended and with all reverence and faithfulnesse improved: And who knoweth but the Lord hath now some controversie with England, which will not be removed, till first and before all, the Worship of his Name and Government of his House, be settled according to his own will: This Ʋniformity they conceive to be most acceptable to God, the surest mean to preserve a solide Peace, without which it can never be expected, and a way to prevent all Heresies and Sects who rent asunder the bowels of Kirk and Kingdom. And the Lords of Secret Councell joyned with the Assembly in these their desires.

Pag. 600. & deinceps. The Parliament (in their Declaration sent in Answer to a former of ours, thanks the Kirk and Kingdom of Scotland for their desires of Unity in Religion and Uniformity in Church Government in his Majesties three Kingdoms, Sheweth, That whensoever Religion is subverted or changed in the one, it will easily be accomplished in the other, And desires that we may mutually
rejoyce in one anothers happinesse, and yeeld his Majestie such a faithfull subjection as may be honourable to himself, comfortable to his people, and advantagious to the Reformed Churches abroad: Declareth, that they have ever made it their chiefest aime, The Reformation of Church Government and Discipline, and though they finde interruptions and opposition in the prosecution and accomplishment thereof, yet they take our deliverance as a pledge of theirs, hopefull that God will perfit their designes and endeavours of a full Reformation in all matters appertaining to Religion, And acknowledging that this is the greatest honour and Service which God receives from his people, the surest foundation of Glory, strength, and happinesse which he bestows upon any Nation, the best mean to preserve from Sects and Heresies; and to Ʋnite these two Nations: Acknowledgeth our serious thoughts and earnest desires for such an Ʋnity in Religion, as that in all his Majesties Dominions there might be one Confession of Faith, one Directory of Worship, one publike Catechisme, and one form of Church Government, to be an act of Love to them, and of Wisdom to the good of both Churches, for which they are thankfull to God and us: And although it will hardly be punctually and exactly obtained, unlesse some way be found for a mutuall communication and conjunction of Counsels and Debates, in framing that one Form; Yet both intending the same end, proceeding by the same rule of Gods Word, and guided by the same Spirit, They hope by Gods assistance to be so directed, as to cast out whatsoever is offensive to God, or justly displeasing to any Neighbour Church, and so far to agree with their Brethren of Scotland and other Reformed Churches in all substantiall parts of Doctrine, Worship, and Discipline, as both they and we may enjoy all these advantages and conveniences mentioned by us in our last Declaration, viz. In the more strict Union of both Kingdoms, more safe, easie, and comfortable Government of his Majestie, and both to himself and people more free communion in all holy Exercises and duties of Worship, more constant security of Religion, against the bloody practises of Papists, and deceitfull Errours of other Sectaries: They give us hearty thanks for our faithfull and affectionate desires of this so great an advantage for them, And declares that we need not make any Apologie for the same. They further declare, that they are to consult with Godly and Learned Divines, for such a Church-Government as may be most agreeable to Gods holy Word, most apt to procure and conserve the peace of the Church at home, and an happy Ʋnion with the Church of Scotland, and other Reformed Churches abroad; And for that effect, do desire us to send some Godly and Learned Divines of our Church to that Assembly of theirs, whereby an Ʋniformity in Form of Church Government may be obtained, and thereby a more easie passage made to the settling of one Confession of Faith, one Directory of publike Worship, and one Catechisme in all the three Kingdoms, which they hope (through Gods blessing) will have such an effect in all his Majesties Dominions, as will much advance the honour and Service of God, enlarge the greatnesse, power, and glory of the King, confirm the peace, security, and prosperity of all his good Subjects, make way to the relief and deliverance of the poor afflicted Churches abroad, and will tend to the ruine Antichrist.

In all the Letters and Declarations of the Conservers of the Peace, there is a clear evidence of our earnest pressing Unity in Religion and Peace, with all respect and tendernesse to his Majesties authority and the Subjects Liberty, And the Parliament of England answers 20 October, That they were willing to concur in all good wayes for the Kings Honour and Happinesse, and Unity and Amity between the Kingdoms, Likeas in all their Declarations they expresse their desires for Uniformity in Religion and preservation of his Majesties authority.

Pag. 659. The Parliament in their publike Declaration emitted to the world after the Battell of Keinton, sent to Scotland, and given by Colonel Pickering in Answer to the Kings Objection, That they countenance Brownists and Anabaptists;
They affirme it to be false and groundlesse: And, that if his Majestie had not denied his consent to the Bill for an Assembly of Divines, they had long since manifested to the world, by a well settled Reformation, their utter dislike of Brownisme and Anabaptisme: But they declare it is one of the Stratagems of the Prelaticall and Malignant partie, to interrupt them in the means to settle Church Government, that by delay thereof they may stir up Factions and Divisions amongst the people, who having not the Rule before them, are apt to run severall wayes, and so to impute the Errors and indiscreet carriage of a few persons unto the Parliament: But God (they hope) in his good time, will unmask their Plots and confound their devices.

Pag. 840. The like Objection is made by the King in his Answer to the Londoners Petition, where it is asked, If the cherishing and countenancing of Brownists and Anabaptists, and all manner of Sectaries, be the way to defend and maintain the true Protestant Religion, And pag. 845. M. Pimme in his Speech to the Citizens of London, in name, and by command of the Parliament answers that Objection amongst others, By denying that the Honourable Houses do give any such countenance to Sectaries, of any kinde whatsoever, and that no such thing can be proved, and retorteth the Argument upon his Majesties keeping of Papists in his Armie. And pag. 442. the King gives direction to his Judges to stop the over-hasty growth of Anabaptisme and other Schismes. They declare pag. 19. of their Remonstrance, That it is far from their desires and intentions to let loose the reins of Discipline and Church Government, to let private persons or particular Congregations take up what form of Worship they please, but do hold it requisite that there should be throughout the whole Realm, a conformity to that order which the Law enjoyns, according to the Word of God.

But above all, let the Declaration directed and sent to the Kingdom of Scotland 7. Novem. 1642. and delivered to that State by Colonel Pickering, be remembred; mentioning, That Scotland had lovingly invited them to a neerer and higher degree of Union in matters concerning Religion and Church Government, which they have most willingly and affectionately embraced, and intend to pursue, declaring also that a great cause and incentive of the Malice of the Prelaticall and Malignant partie against them, proceeds from the designe they have to hinder the Reformation of the Ecclesiasticall Government in this Kingdom, so much longed for by all the true Lovers of the Protestant Religion: And therefore against such their malice and power, they implore the speedy and powerfull assistance of their Brethren of Scotland, according to the late Act of Pacification, Common dutie of Christianity, and the particular interests of their own Kingdom, which assistance they hope shall produce the preservation of Religion, the honour, safety, and peace of his Majestie and all his Subjects, and a more strict conjunction of the Counsels, Designes, and Endeavours of both Nations, for the comfort and relief of the Reformed Churches beyond Sea. All which we did beleeve, and desire to be performed, And did not beleeve the Kings Answer thereunto immediately sent to Scotland against them, as intending to countenance Sects and Schismes, and to subvert his Royall authority.

In August 1643. The English Commissioners in their first Proposition desire some from our Assembly to be sent to England, to perfit that work of Reformation of Church Government, and acknowledge that what corruptions take root in England will quickly spread their venome and infection to the Neighbour Church of Scotland, and to ingage us, they presse our interest (although now it is urged by some that we have none) that they were appointed to consult with us concerning such things as might conduce to their Reformation, and their so much desired conjunction with the Church of Scotland.

The Parliaments Declaration given in by their Commissioners acknowledgeth our Christian Zeal and Love in our Endeavours for the necessary Reformation
of their Church Government and more neer Union of both Churches: And that the two Honourable Houses fully concur with us in these pious intentions, for accomplishment whereof they had called an Assembly and sent down Commissioners, desiring us to give them credit in all things they propose, They call it the cause of God, and shew that we cannot enjoy Religion, Peace, and Liberty, if they be sub • erted in England, the Commissioners invite us to be instruments of a glorious Reformation in England, that God had put in the hearts of both, desires of a neerer Union in Church Government, and for defence against the common Enemies, That God would make use of this opportunity, to knit them both to himself, and each to other in a most strict and durable Union, And thereby the more firmly to establish Truth and Peace in both Nations.

The same is repeated in their Paper to the Convention of Estates, that the designe of subverting Religion was the same, but mutata methodo, That they would secure us from the Invasion of the Irish Rebels, That they needed not Arguments to invite us to their assistance, Since now the Honourable Houses have so fully declared by what they have done, and what they are desirous to doe, that the true State of the Cause and Quarrell is Religion: In Reformation whereof they are so forward and zealous, as there is nothing expressed in our former or latter Declarations, which they have not seriously taken to heart, and seriously endeavoured to effect, that so the two Kingdoms might be brought to a neerer conjunction in form of Church Government, Directory, Confession, and Catechisme, and utter extirpation of Prelacie. The most effectuall and ready mean whereunto, is now conceived to be the stricter Union and League between the Nations and our assistance of England by an Army.

And in the Letter from the Assembly of Divines by order of the House of Commons, they call it twice the Cause of Religion, thanketh us for our desires of Uniformity, and imports their laying out a Discipline most agreeable to Gods Word, most apt to preserve the Peace of the Church at home, and neerer agreement with the Church of Scotland, and other Reformed Churches, that so to the utmost of their power, they may exalt him who is the onely Lord, over his Church, his own house, in all his offices, and present the Church as a chaste Virgin unto Christ. They mention the Oath of Assembly concerning Discipline, viz. What they conceive most to the glory of God, and good and peace of his Church, and clears the freedom of Assembly to serve their consciences.

The Assemblies Answer to the Parliament, desires that it may be more and more cleared, Religion to be the true state of the differences in England, and to be uncessantly prosecute first and above all things, Giving no sleep to their eyes, no slumber to their eye-lids, untill it be settled; and twice or thrice mentioneth their three Motives, and three ends of Covenant, whereunto they desired the Parliaments concurrence, And so they write to the King, And so in their Answer to the Assembly of Divines and Ministers of England, both for Uniformity and the Kings Authority.

div.head: THE FOVRTH PAPER Delivered in to the Houses OF PARLIAMENT BY THE COMMISSIONERS OF SCOTLAND: Containing their Reasons, Why the RESULT of the Committee of both Kingdomes at EDINBURGH 28. Novemb. 1643. is a TREATY.
div.p: COncerning the difference about the Treaty at Edinburgh 28 November 1643. for the better understanding of the whole businesse, we shall speak of these heads. First, of the state and condition of affairs before, and at the time of the making of this Treaty. Secondly, of the powers to make this Treaty. Thirdly, of the Treaty and the conditions thereof. Fourthly, of the confirmation of this Treaty, and the performance thereof. And fifthly, we shall answer the Objections that are alledged why this is not a Treaty.

Concerning the state of affaires before the making of the Treaty, it was this, The Kingdome of Scotland, according to an agreement made with the Kingdome of England, the 4 of Ianuary 1642. and the Treaty of the 6 August. 1642. sent over an Army into Vlster in Ireland, for suppressing the rebellion in that Kingdome, where they had not long continued, but troubles did arise in this Kingdome, upon the occasion of the difference between the King and his Parliament; whereby the supplies promised for entertainment of that Army were withdrawn for the maintenance of the war here, and the Scottish Army was driven to so great extremities, that hundreds of them were starved for want of bread, as hath been formerly represented to the Houses. About the month of Iuly 1643. the enemies power prevailing so farre in England, as they were possessed of the most part of the Kingdome, the Houses of Parliament did resolve, and accordingly sent Commissioners into the Kingdome of Scotland, to Treat concerning the sending of an Army into England, for assistance of their Brethren in England, as also to Treat concerning the Scottish Army in Ireland, gave them credentiall Letters to the Estates of Scotland, with ample power to negotiate, treat, and conclude, and desired the Kingdome of Scotland to give them full credit in what they should propound. The English Commissioners, at first desired the removeall of the Scottish Army, because the Houses of Parliament had found themselves unable to support the charges of that warre: But not long after their arrivall, Generall Major Monro acquaints the Kingdome of Scotland with the state of affaires in Ireland, sends over the Letters directed to him from the Lord Lieutenant, and Lord Justices of Ireland, requiring him to agree to the Cessation, and declareth his inability to resist the English and Irish, joyned together, especially when hee wanted the meanes of subsistance.

Further, the Scottish Army sends Commissioners into Scotland to represent their wants, the necessity of providing a speedy supply of a considerable summe of Money and Victuals, for their present subsistance, without which they would bee constrained to come away. And these supplies being granted, that as a necessary mean for prosecution of the War, the English Army having revolted from the Parliament, the British Forces (who except a very few, are all of the Scottish Nation) might be joyned with them under one command in chiefe, for opposing the Cessation. Likewise many thousands of the Inhabitants did petition the Estates of Scotland for the same purpose, and declared that they would be constrained to desert the Countrey, if the Scottish Army were forced to remove: All which being communicated to the English Commissioners, they dispatched away to the Houses, and in the meane time wrote to Generall Major Monro, encouraging him to withstand the Cessation, and shewing that they were sent from the Parliament of England, and had power to treat and conclude in such things as concerned
that Army, and to give good satisfaction to the desires of their Commissioners sent to the Convention of Estates.

The Houses of Parliament in September 1643. being acquainted with the state of Affaires in Ireland, findeth necessary to continue the Scottish Army in Ireland, and in their instructions of the first of November, appoint their Commissioners to make knowne to their Brethren of Scotland the Votes of both Houses, declaring the Cessation in Ireland destructive to the Protestant Religion, dishonourable to the English Nation, and prejudicial to the interest of the three Kingdomes; and further, appoint them to make knowne that it was the resolution of both Houses to oppose to the utmost the said Cessation, and to encourage, so faras lyes in their power, all those Forces Scottish and British, for the utter subduing of those Rebels, and the preventing of setting up Popery in that Kingdome: and in particular for encouragement of the Scottish Army, that they will hasten away with all speed the 60000. l. promised, the 10000. suits of cloathes, and other necessaries. These directions being returned, and the Agents sent from the Army, being sensible of the great straights and imminent dangers the Army was in, do instantly presse a speedy agreement to their demands, and present advance of a considerable summe of money and quantitie of victualls, without which they will not undertake to stay. And having been disappointed for 16. or 17. moneths together of any supply from England, they altogether decline to Treat with the English Commissioners, but will have the engagement of the Kingdom of Scotland for whatsoever is promised them. And upon the other part the English Commissioners will not Treat with the Army, but with the Committee of Estates, and earnestly presse their concurrence in giving satisfaction to the demands of the Army, and perswading them to stay. These who seriously considered the affaires of Scotland, how great an Army they were to send into England, and what danger the Kingdome, so much weakned of Forces, would be exposed to (whereof since they have sad experience) did incline to the bringing of that Army out of Ireland, (some Garrisons excepted, according to the first desires of the English Commissioners communicated to the States and Army) and so to make up a part of the Armie to be sent into England, which would lessen the charge and expence of the Leavy of the Foot by the halfe, and make us stronger at home for suppressing any insurrection, and defending our selves from any invasion that should happen. Also the Army was more desirous to come into England where they had hopes of subsistance, then continue in Ireland where they had experience of very great want. But when it was considered, that if Scotland did not presently interpose for the stay of their Army, in all probabilitie, the Kingdome of Ireland would be resigned into the hands of the Rebels, and the remainder of the well affected in that Kingdome exposed to their cruelty. The Estates of Scotland being immediatly before joyned in Covenant
for so good ends with their Brethren of England, and to drowne their peace in the sea of Englands warre, resolved to decline no hazard or danger whatsoever in prosecution of this cause. And (though then free) did engage themselves for a present supply of money and victualls to enable the stay of that Armie, till the Kingdome of England should send further supplies for their subsistance.

Concerning the powers for making of this Treaty, the Committee of Estates of Scotland had full and ample power to Treat, agree, and conclude in all things concerning that Army: And that no doubt may remaine here, (if any be) it was the same Committee that did authorize the Covenant and Treaty for England, and had a generall power concerning the whole affaires of the Kingdome.

As to the powers of the Commissioners for the Parliament of England, they had credentiall Letters, signed by the two Speakers in the name of the two Houses of Parliament: Which Letters say, That the Houses had given their Commissioners ample power to negotiate, treat, and conclude; and do desire the Kingdome of Scotland to beleeve whatsoever they should propound. And againe, the Houses in their answer to the Kingdome of Scotland, sent by Master Meldrum, say, That they have enabled their Commissioners with ample instructions in their names to treat, agree, and conclude all Questions, Doubts, and Demands concerning the arreare and future pay of that Armie, and the continuance or removeall of the same. And (although we are not obliged to enquire after their particular instructions, when their power in generall is so ample) they have by their instructions expresse power for setling the accompts of that Armie; concerning the proportion of the supplies to bee sent to them, and the time of payment is left to their judgement: Concerning the managing of the War in Ireland, they are expreslie authorized, presently to setle the same to be done by the joynt advice of Committees of both Kingdomes, for preventing the evils and mischiefes that else might fall out, and are onely to make knowne to the Houses what they doe, which is required at the hands of all that are intrusted by any Prince or State, bee their power never so great. And of this power the Commissioners of the Houses did not make the strict use, but agreed upon an alternative, leaving it to the Election of the Houses of Parliament which to choose, the stay of the Armie in Ireland, upon performance of the Conditions they were appointed to offer; or let the Armie come from thence to bee a part of the Scottish Army that was to be sent into England. And what could the Kingdome of Scotland do more then this? What was in their owne power to determine as they pleased for the interest and good of their owne affaires, they leave it to the determination of their Brethren to choose either of the two, as they thought most conduceable for the affaires of England.

As to the Treaty and conditions thereof, the Estates of the Kingdome
of Scotland, and the Commssioners of the Parliament of England, having taken into consideration the dangerous estate of the Affairs of Ireland, and the demands of the Scottish Army, to be forthwith transported out of Ireland, or otherwise if they be desired to stay, that they may have a considerable supply of money, and other necessaries presently furnished unto them, assurance given for their future pay, the British joyned with them, and a course setled for managing the warre.

They agree upon 7. Articles, which may be drawne into three heads: First, that the Armie shall stay in Ireland till the first of February, and to enable them, there shall be presently advanced by the Committee of Estates and the English Commissioners 10000. suits of cloathes, 10000. paire of shooes, 10000. bolls of meale, and 10000. l. in money, and the accompts of the Armie shall bee presentlie made up and concluded. 2. They agree upon an alternative, That betwixt and the first of February, 50000. l. shall be really payed and delivered to the Armie, that assurance and security shall be given for their future monthly pay, That he who commands in chiefe over the Scottish Armie, by joynt advice of both Kingdomes, shall command the rest of the British forces in Ireland, and that the warre shal be managed by the joynt advice of Committees of both Kingdomes: and in this case the Armie shall be obliged to stay, but in case these conditions shall not be really performed, that then the Armie shall be transported upon the Parliament of Englands charge to such parts of England as they shall receive orders for from the General of the Scottish Army, and shalbe maintained according to the same establishment as shall be appointed for the Scottish Armie, and the Parliament of England to stand still obliged for their whole arrears according to the Treatle of the 6. of August.
It was agreed, that whether they stay in Ireland or come from thence, 5000. Armes should be sent unto them.

The first and last of these are agreed upon without any reservation, and the second is agreed on by way of alternative, leaving it to the election of the Parliament of England, which they should think fit to choose, yet so as by this Treatie they are positively obliged to the performance of one of the two, wherein the words of the Treaty are very emphatick, when upon a narrative of the former extremities of the Army, it sayes, It is therefore now agreed, &c. The conditions are mutuall, the Kingdome of Scotland perswades the Army to stay upon such and such conditions, whom they might have made use of for their owne service; and further, they become suretie for England that these conditions shall bee performed. The Army thereupon engage themselves, and according to the custome observed in that Kingdome in the like cases, enact themselves to stay according to the conditions and termes agreed upon, and a copie of the Act was delivered to the English Commissioners upon the other part, as was demanded by the Army, and offered by
the Houses of Parliament: the Kingdome of Scotland is interessed in the managing of the warre during the stay of their Army, and such course is setled as may enable them to prosecute the warre according to the Covenant. This is all the new obligation on Englands part, as for the supply of moneyes and other necessaries in this particular, the agreement is made much for Englands advantage; for whereas they were obliged by a former Treatie for present payment of the whole arreares, the Army is perswaded for the present to accept of the 5. or 6. part of their arrears, and that not to bee payd till two months after the Treatie. This is the sum of the agreement wherein Scotland, formerly bound by no such condition either to England or to the Army, now engage themselves to both and for both, upon conditions reciprocally to be performed by the Kingdome of England; Here is a quid pro quo, and what thing essentiall to a Treatie is deficient, Obligatio oritur ex contractu, vel quasi, contractus ex consensu reliteris, verbis, and all these are here, nay, what formality is wanting, for this Treaty is signed by the Clerks of both Kingdomes, and ratified by the Parliaments of both respectively: It hath al the names that can be desired, for it is called by the Houses a Result, an Agreement, a Treaty, A transaction between the Kingdoms, and if there were any formality wanting, whereunto we did not look so narrowly, nor stand upon, after such a Covenant, & our engagements to stand and fall with this Kingdome; the lesse Ceremony in such an exigent there was the more confidence, and consequentlie there ought to be the stricter performance, ubi majorsides ibistrictior observantia, and it is to be considered, that in Treaties between Nations, formalities are different, and as there is no law of Nations concerning formalities and circumstances of Treaties, so there is no agreement or constant practice about them betweene these Kingdomes in particular.

Before wee speake of the confirmation and performance of this Treatie we shall premise two things. First, that propositions were framed by the Committee of Estates of Scotland and the Commissioners of both Houses, the 25. August 1643. concerning the sending of an Army into England, in the preamble of which, it is expresly set down, that these propositions were to be certified with all convenient speed to the two Houses of the Parliament of England, and the Convention of Estates of Scotland, to bee respectivelie taken into their considerations, and proceeded with as they shall finde cause, which expressions are not set down in the preamble of these Articles of the 28. November, 1643. Onely because there is an alternative in the Treaty, therefore they are to be presented to the Houses who had power to make choise of the stay of the Army, or of their removeall at the first of February, according to the respective conditions mentioned in the Treaty, but are positively obliged to the Election of one of two, as may appear by these words, (It is agreed, and it is now agreed) prefixed to the severall articles, which is not
done in the propositions of the 25 of August. Secondly, that upon the 22. of Ianuary 1642. the Commissioners of the Kingdome of Scotland then residing here, having received a Proposition from the Committee of both Houses for transporting to Ireland 2500. men then on foot in Scotland, declared they had no instructions so to do till the closure of the Treaty, but were content to offer some propositions to the Houses of Parliament, which being granted, they would represent the desires of the Houses to the Councell of Scotland; and upon the 24. of Ianuary, these propositions being presented to the Houses, they did agree unto them, and upon the 26. and 27. of Ianuary, they were approved by his Majestie: these were only Propositions, and propositions to be presented to the Councel of Scotland, yet after they were consented unto by the Councell of Scotland, it was an obligatory agreement betweene the Kingdomes. We now come to the confirmation of this Treaty, which being agreed upon at Edinburgh, and signed by the Clerks of the Committees of both Kingdomes; The English Commissioners upon the 30. of November, dispatch away the same to the Houses, with a Letter, wherein they shew the dangerous estate of Ireland, and that in case of the coming away of the Scottish Army, that Kingdome would be resigned up into the hands of the Rebels, that the Parliament had enabled them to promise, but not to performe, or words to that sense: and the Committee of the Estates of Scotland gave instructions to their Commissioners, about that time repairing to London, to desire the Parliament of England to confirme that Treaty, and speedily to performe the conditions therein agreed upon; and accordingly the Commissioners of Scotland so soone as they come to London, and a Committee was appointed by the Houses to Treat with them, gave in a Paper upon the 17. of February, to be presented to the Houses for that purpose; and upon the 9. of March, both Houses confirmed the 1, 2, 4, 6, and 7. Articles, whereof that of the managing of the Warre is one, and in ratifying of the 6. Article, the Houses do expresly call it a Treaty. Further, the Houses in answer to the Paper of the Commissioners of the Kingdome of Scotland, appoint the Committees of both Houses, to deliver these Votes of the 9. of March, as their consent to the 1, 2, 4, 6, and 7. Articles of the Result of the Committees of both Kingdomes, which was done accordingly. Concerning the 3, and 5. Articles they returne this answer, That the extremities and wants of this Kingdome were so great, as though they used their endeavours to provide, that 10000. l. present, and 50000. l. in February, yet it was not come in, but they hoped within some short time to do it. And because in this case the Scottish Army was not obliged to stay, as is agreed upon expresly in the 5. Article: for preventing their coming away, the Houses doe desire the Kingdome of Scotland to co-operate with them so far as lyeth in their power, to keep the said Army in Ireland, for the prosecution of the Warre against the
bloudy Rebels: And do promise, That so far as is possible for the Parliament of England to doe for the speedy providing of the 60000. l. and setling of a course for their future pay, they will apply themselves thereunto with all readinesse and care: in the meane time the 50000. l. not being payed to the Army at February, according to the agreement: The Army gathers together the Ships, and Barks in those parts, presently to transport themselves; and before it was possible for the Kingdome of Scotland to give any stop, three of the Regiments landed in Scotland, in a very mutinous posture, with intention to Leavy moneys upon the Kingdome of Scotland for payment of their arreares. And on the other hand there were great grievances amongst the people, by reason of the great taxes and burthens laid upon them, for raising and maintaining the Army sent into England, and for reliefe of the Army in Ireland, and particularly by reason of the Excise, which being a thing which wanted the practise of former times, and onely for the maintenance of Armies in other Kingdomes, occasioned no small disturbance amongst the people, as the Commissioners of the Parliament can bear witnesse. But notwithstanding all these difficulties (whereof we hope the Honourable Houses will never be forgetfull) The Estates of Scotland being verie desirous, so far as was in their power, to co-operate with the Parliament of England for the stay of that Armie, forthwith gave power to their Committees (a thing very unusuall in that Kingdome, even in the greatest exigents) to call before them all persons that were able of themselves, or by their credit, to lend or raise moneyes, and to require and ordaine them to lend or give security for such sums of money as they conceived to be proportionable to their estates. And with power to these Committees, in case of refusall, to take such course with them, as in so urgent a necessity they should think fit, to make them advance moneyes, as is before expressed. And by this meanes a considerable proportion of moneyes and provision was forthwith sent to Ireland to move them to stay, which they did accordingly. About the beginning of April, by the report of Master Traile, and Letters from Scotland, these things were made knowne to the Houses, and that the Armie had thereupon condescended to stay, notwithstanding they had received no supply from England for 20. moneths together. This was also recapitulated in a Paper of the 3. of April by the Commissioners of Scotland, who upon these considerations, presse the further resolution of the Houses about the 3. and 5. Articles of the Result of 28. of November, shewing that they had no power to do any more or otherwise then was therein agreed: and withall desiring the Houses, in case any emergent necessitie of businesse here should interrupt the accomplishment thereof, to declare the resolution according to the 5. Article of the Result, and in a Paper of the 6. of April, the Commissioners of the Kingdome of Scotland doe positively desire the Houses to take into consideration the present
supply and future subsistance of that Armie, or of transporting and disposing of them otherwise to the good of both Kingdomes, and of giving their last resolution concerning the one or the other, to the Convention of Estates and to the Army, now after foure moneths attendance upon their answer, since the conditions were agreed upon at Edinburgh, whereupon the Houses on the 11. of April, resolve and promise, That by the 15. of May, 30000. l. should bee provided, and the remainder thereof by the last of Iune: and say it is that whereupon the Armie may depend, and for the future maintenance of the Scottish and British Forces, that 4000. l. should be payed monthly to the Scottish Army, and the like sum monthly to the British Forces, and the surplusage due to the Scottish Forces, according to the Treaty over and above the said 4000. l. monthly, to be secured to them upon the publick Faith. Concerning the Commander in chief; they declare that the Earle of Leven is Commander in chief of the British, as well as Scots, according to the 4. Article of the Result of the Committees of both Kingdomes, passed both Houses, which they mention in these Votes, as the ground obliging them in that particular, and desire his Excellence to appoint a Commander in chief in his absence: and for the managing of the war, they resolve that Committees be nominated, and appointed by the joynt advice of both Kingdomes to reside on the place for regulation of these Forces, and better carrying on of that Warre.

Further, upon the 25. of May, the honourable Houses of Parliament wrote a letter to the Parliament of Scotland, acquainted them that they had ratified and confirmed the severall Treaties made and agreed between their Commissioners and the Estates of Scotland, and it is their desire the same may be done by the Parliament of Scotland. Also they professe themselves, verie sensible of the great wants and extremities which the Scottish Armie in Ireland hath borne with much patience, occasioned by the manifold distractions and great necessities of this Kingdome, and doe returne their heartie thanks to the Kingdome of Scotland, for their care of that Army, and the great charge they have been at for their relief, with provisions and money for their necessarie subsistance: They likewise in that letter make knowen what they have done in pursuance of their resolutions of the 11. of April, and promise performance of the rest according to the said resolutions, by all which it is most cleare and evident, that the Houses did choose the first part of the alternative concerning the stay of the Army, whereas if they had seasonablie chosen the last part concerning their transport, the Kingdome of Scotland had been free of a great burthen of entertaining that Armie in Ireland, and needed not to have beene at the charge of raising so many foot to bring into England. We come now to answer the objections, which as at the debate we desired to know, if we repeated them faithfully, so if there be any mistake now we shall upon information be readie to rectifie the same.
It is objected from the preamble of this Treatie, that these were only propositions to be presented to the Houses, and so onely preparatory for their resolution, without any obligation of a Treatie.

To which we answer. That the reason of this was because the Treatie consisted of an alternative, and it was left to the Houses to choose the one part of the alternative or the other, with the conditions therein expressed, but in all other things the Treatie was then fully agreed upon, as may appear by comparing them with the propositions of the 25. of August, in the preamble of which it is clearly expressed, that the Parliament of England, or convention of Estates, may alter or change them as they shall finde cause: but there is no such expression in the preamble of these, onely it is said they were agreed upon to be presented to the Houses, and these not as naked propositions, but as particulars already agreed to by their Commissioners, as is prefixed to the Articles, to the end they migh thee confirmed: Only this was left free, that the Houses might make election of one part of the Alternative, and that it is not also to bee presented to the convention of Estates or Parliament of Scotland, is as cleare, for that the Committee of Estates did not reserve a power to determine concerning the stay or removeall of the Army, but left the same to the Houses of Parliament, upon the conditions expressed in the agreement, and therefore did finally conclude for their part upon the whole, the exigent beeing such as would not admit of a delay, till the meeting of the Parliament in May following, because things were presently to be performed in matter of supply and accompts, to perswade the stay of the Army till the first of February: And there was also a necessitie of giving satisfaction to the Army presentlie, what should be their conditions, if they should be desired to stay after the first of February, and what should bee their conditions if they came away, which were then agreed upon by both Kingdomes: Onely concerning the alternative there was no determination for the present on Englands part, it being at the desire of the Commissioners left to the election of the Houses. And whereas it was affirmed that these Articles were not obligatory, we leave it to the Houses and all understanding men to judge, whether this could have given any satisfaction to the Army to stay, or the Kingdome of Scotland to engage, if it had been then said unto them by the Commissioners of the Parliament of England, We wil make an agreement with you, but it must not be obligatory but alterable at the pleasure of the Parliament of England. But for a further answer, consider the propositions of the 24. of Ianuary 1642. these were onely propositions, and propositions to be presented to the Councell of Scotland alone, the Houses having alreadie agreed, and the Commissioners of Scotland having declared they had no power in that particular, yet we believe there is none will say that after the Councell of Scotland had also agreed to these propositions, notwithstanding their consent, they were not obliged to send the 2500 men into Ireland,
or when Scotland had performed their part, that the Kingdome of England was not obliged to performe the conditions agreed unto on their part, but might alter them at their pleasure; And how much more ought this agreement to be observed where nothing essentiall to a Treatie, nor any necessarie formalitie is wanting, seeing also the propositions of the 25. of August, that were unquestionably alterable by the Houses, are after confirmation esteemed a Treaty obligatory, and not alterable at pleasure of one of the parties, which we conceave to be essentiall to all Treaties made between Nations, or contracts between persons, &c. they being primo libertatis sed postea necessitatis, free before consent, but not after, neither can it make any materiall difference, that the propositions of the 25. of August, were afterward signed by the Commissioners of both Kingdomes, the authority being all one whether they be subscribed by Commissioners or Clerks of the Parliament of both Kingdomes: for the agreement the 24. of Ianuary 1642. and the Treaty concerning the sending the Scottish Army into Ireland 6. August 1642. are only signed by the Clerks of the two Parliaments respectively.

But sayes the opponent, It is acknowledged to bee a Treaty between the Kingdomes, and to bee an agreement between the Kingdoms, but not a Treaty with such and such formalities, it is a Treaty in one sense, but not in such a sense as the other Treaties; they are obligatory, and this is not.

1. This seems to us very strange Doctrine, since there is no law of Nations nor constant practise or custome between these Kingdoms, concerning the formalities of a Treaty, we never understood such a distinction of Treaties and agreement between Kingdoms before, as some obligatory and some not; and to tell us now, and never till now, two yeares and a halfe after the agreement, and after Scotland hath performed their part of it, that this is not a Treaty in that sense that other Treaties are; Whatsoever be the mindes of private persons, we trust it will be very farre from the Honourable Houses of Parliament to approve of such a distinction: And how ever it may relish with some now, it would have been very evil Rhethorick, the 28. of November 1643. to perswade the Scots Army to stay in Ireland, or the Kingdome of Scotland to engage for their intertainment, to say in plain English, there are diverse senses and diverse natures of Treaties, some that are not, and some that are alterable at pleasure, of one of the parties, and that after their owne confirmation and performance made by the other partie. 2. Another objection was, that they are of the nature of Ordinances, and containe nothing which may imply the construction of a Treaty.

To which we answer. 1. That the votes of the 9. of March, were delivered unto us by the appointment of both houses as their consent to the Articles of the Result and Treaty of the Committee of both Kingdomes 28. of November 1643. and the Kingdom of Scotland is thereupon desired by the Houses to co-operate with them so
farre as was in their power, for stay of that Army in Ireland. 2. These Articles are ratified as things past of the same date. 3. The Committee of the Estates of Scotland are therein made undertakers and advancers of moneys and provisions, who can no way come under the power of an ordinance of the Houses of Parliament. 4. The votes of the 11. of April, do mention the Result of the 28. of November, passed both Houses as the foundation and obligation upon which they are grounded, and suppose it were an Ordinance, it beeing made to satisfie another Nation engaged in an agreement at their desire, and to answer the demands of an Army of strangers, whom they had taken on in their service, and for 20. monthes together left destitute of all manner of supply, we hope the Houses will not judge such an Ordinance alterable at pleasure. 5. We have no other confirmation of the propositions of the 24. of Ianuary, nor of the Treatie of the 6. of August, but the votes of the Houses in the same manner.

2 It was objected that in the propositions of peace formerly agreed on, all the Treaties are enumerated together and desired to be confirmed, and this Treaty is not there enumerated, but is named as an Ordinance.

We answer. That at the framing of the propositions it was conceived inconvenient to present that whole Treaty to the King, because it would lay open too much to our enemies the wants and distresses of that Army, and in particular, it was conceived, not necessary to desire ratification of that part which looked to the time past, but onely what related to the future, which was mainly the Article concerning the Command in chiefe, and managing of the war. And it being agreed upon in the 17. proposition that the Militia of the Kingdomes should be setled in Commissioners of both Kingdomes, and that as a joynt Committee, they should have power to order the warre of Ireland, according to the ordinance of the 11. of April, (which is founded upon the result of the 28. of November, as is therein expressed) And further, to order the Militia, and conserve the peace of the Kingdome of Ireland, this was judged equivalent to the enumeration of it, amongst the other Treaties, and carryed this further advantage with it, That it did avoyd the inconveniences afore mentioned. This was the true reason of the omitting of it in that place, and provided that the 17. proposition may stand as formerly, we shall not desire this Treaty to be expressed any other wayes, or in any other place: and why any mistake of expression in us, who did not then make such a difference (as now we have cause to doe) betwixt a Treaty and an Ordinance, or votes reciting the substance thereof, and in the body of it mentioning the Treaty as the obligation on which it was founded, should be urged as an argument to prove this no Treaty, we cannot understand, sith the Houses of Parliament do alledge that they are not only not obliged to expressions made in these propositions, but also may, and
also have changed the most materiall things in these Propositions. Certainly if one of the Kingdomes be not obliged to the matter or forme of these Propositions, the other is not. But that it may sufficiently appear to the Honourable Houses, that wee have no other thoughts now then we had then, and so farre as we know, was then also the minde of the Houses themselves: We desire that our Paper of the 28. of October, 1644. may be perused, which was delivered into the Houses immediatly upon the concluding of the Propositions, and before they were sent to Oxford, wherein wee desire, that according to the 6. Article of the Treaty at Edinburgh 28. November, 1643. confirmed by the Houses in their Votes of the 9. of March, there be sent over to Carickfergus 5000. Armes, for the use of the Scottish Armie, and an answer thereunto, the House of Commons do call it, The Treaty at Edinburgh, the 28. November, since confirmed by the Houses in their Votes of the 9. of March, and upon that reference the Committee of both Houses having conferred with us, and reported their opinions, both Houses gave order for furnishing of those Armies accordingly.
4. Objection was, That the Kingdome of Scotland did call from Ireland some of that Army for their own assistance.

To this wee answer. 1.
