That when the Houses of Parliament desired the Kingdome of Scotland to send an Army into England for their assistance, their Commissioners gave in a Paper to the Convention of Estates in these words, [And for the better encouragement of the Kingdome of Scotland to this necessary and so much desired Vnion, we are by both Houses of Parliament authorized to assure their Brethren, That if they shall be annoyed or indangered by any Force or Armie, either from England, or from any other place, the Lords and Commons in England will assist them with a proportionable strength of Horse and Foot, to what their Brethren shall now afford them to bee sent into Scotland for the defence of that Kingdome, and they will maintaine a guard of Ships at their owne charge upon the coasts of Scotland, for the securing of that Kingdome from the invasion of the Irish Rebels, or other enemies, during such time as the Scottish Armie shall be imployed in the defence of the Kingdome of England.] And though this was particularly agreed upon by Treaty, yet it is well known to the Houses of Parliament that this was not performed, which considered, wee trust they will have a good construction of the calling away a small number from that Army, for their owne necessary defence against a farre greater number of Irish Rebels.

1 It is provided by the large Treaty between the Kingdomes, that in case any Armies be levyed or neighbours wronged, as the Kingdome of Scotland was in a great measure, by those barbarous Irish subjects of the Crowne of England, The Estates of the country by which it was done, are obliged to pursue, take, and punish the offenders with all rigour. And incase any of the subjects of any of the Kingdomes shall rise in Armes, or make Warre against the
Kingdome or subjects thereof, without consent of the Parliament of that Kingdome whereof they are subjects, or upon which they do depend (which is expressed, because of Irelands dependance on England, under the which, it is agreed in that Treatie to bee comprehended in all the Articles thereof) that they shall be held and demaind as Traitors to the Estate whereof they are subjects; and that State or Kingdome is bound, and gives their publick Faith to concurre with the other to represse them, and if England was bound to send Forces forsuppressing these Rebells, we might with far greater reason recall some of our owne Forces to oppose those very enemies whom they were sent into Ireland to pursue.

3. They were uselesse in Ireland, by reason supplies were not sent them according to the Treaty, to enable them for service there, and were better employed in delivering Scotland from those who had invaded that Kingdome, for no other quarrell but for the assistance sent unto England, and in preventing an invasion of England, which the late Earle of Montrose and the Irish Rebels professed and declared to be their maine intention and designe.

A 5. Objection was, That the Committee of both Houses were appointed to Treat with the Scottish Commissioners here, about the ascertaining the intertainment of the Scottish Army in England; this was a Treaty, but what was done by the Committee of both Houses was not obligatory. We answer. That the Committee of both Houses had no power to Treat, agree and conclude, but only to Treat and report; yea, they were expresly limited not to make a Result, but appointed to report their opinions, with the reasons of the Scottish Commissioners apart: and where there is no power to make a Result, certainly there can be no Treaty; also the case is wholly different, as may be made easily appeare, but because this argument was not insisted upon, wee shall insist on the entring of it.

A 6. Objection was, That the Houses did delay the Ratification of the 3. and 5. Articles, and when they gave their resolution upon them, they varied the dayes for payment of the moneys, and did not ratifie the 5. Article, as it was presented.

Wee cannot see where the strength of this argument lyeth, unlesse it be to commend the readinesse of the Kingdome of Sctoland, who in the interim furnished moneys and provisions to that Armie, and the patience of the Army, who notwithstanding all their former sufferings, did wait for these supplies so long after the time agreed upon in the Treaty. Concerning the not ratifying of the 5. Article, as it was presented, we are forced again to remember that which seemes to be forgotten all along the debate, That there is an Alternative in the 5. Article, and the Houses could not ratifie both parts of the Alternative, which are directly opposite, whereof the one doth concerne their stay, the other their removall.

A 7. Objection was, That there was no stipulation on Scotlands
part, for by the Treatie the 6. of August, the Scottish Army was obliged to stay in Ireland, and if the conditions be not mutuall, and stipulatory, the whole foundation of this Treatie is taken away.

For answer. We desire it may be considered, that the Army, according to the Treaty, was to be monthly payed, and they were not obliged to stay till they were starved, though such were the patience of many of them. But which removes it beyond all exception or scruple the Armie had then, for about 16. moneths received no supplies from England, (which wee beleeve no age can paralell) and the Parliament of England, according to their instructions in Iuly 1643. had declared, their owne troubles did so increase, that they were not able to maintaine them, and therefore desired the Estates of Scotland to withdraw them from Ireland, except a few to bee left for Garrisons, and offered all meanes in the power of the Houses for satisfying their Arrears, according to the Treaty the 6. August. Now being thus dis-ingaged by the Parliament of England in August, and the Army thereupon willing to come away, they were not obliged to stay, when afterwards upon no • ice of the Revolt of the Parliaments Forces, and making a Cessation with the Irish Rebels, their stay was found necessary, and desired by England: Neither was the Kingdome of Scotland at all obliged to entertaine that Army, nor to send them supplies, as they did engage themselves to do by this second Treaty, at the desire of the Parliament of England.

It was lastly objected, That these Articles were of a diverse nature, six of them are obligatorie, as being grounded upon the Treaty of the 6. of August, but that concerning the managing of the war is of another nature, having no quid pro quo, neither was it the cause of the stay of the Army, and therefore not obligatorie, and though the whole Articles were obligatory, yet the Kingdome of England failing in performance to Scotland, the Kingdome of Scotland was free to break on the other side, and there is an end of the Treaty.

This of all other appeares to be most strange, for it makes no difference between a Treaty and Common discourse, if one Kingdome break to another, suppose it were in the least cirumstance, the other Kingdome is by this tenet set at liberty to breake in the whole, and so the Treaty to be for ever dissolved, as if it had never been. To this we shall answer no further, but that this argument makes a Treaty (which is a thing most sacred and inviolable to be keept between Kingdomes) to be of such a nature as either Kingdome may dissolve it at pleasure, without any reparation to be had, or account to be sought by the other, and consequently there is not, nor cannot be any obligatory Treaty between the Kingdomes. To the first part of the Argument, that six of the Articles are obligatory and one is not. We answer, that by the Treaty of the 6. of August, the Parliament of England was obliged to pay the whole arreares of the Army, extending then to above three hundreth thousand pounds
sterling, as may appeare by the accompts signed, and concluded by the English Commissioners immediatly after this Treaty, 28. Novemb. 1643. And in this new Treaty the Army was content for that present to accept of the 5. or 6. part of their arreares, and beecause they had been so often disappointed of what was promised them, they demanded this further security, That the Kingdome of Scotland might be surety for Englands performance, which they had not in the Treaty of the 6. of August, some of these Articles are not at all mentioned in the Treaty of the 6. of August, as the 6. and 7. Articles, and the rest, though they may have the same matter with some Articles of the Treaty of the 6. of August, yet are they agreed upon in a different manner: And that it may appear that the 4. Article of this Treaty concerning the Command in chiefe, and managing of the Warre, is not altogether now, as this Objection seemes to hold forth, we desire it may be remembred, that in the 3. Article of the Propositions of the 24. of Ianuary, 1642. it is agreed, That if it shall be thought fit that any Regiments or Troupes of Vlster shall joyne with the Scots Forces, that they shall receive Orders from the Commander of the Scottish Forces, and in the 9. Article of the Treaty of the 6. of August, it is agreed that the inhabitants of all Townes and villages in Ireland, where the Scottish Armie shall be, the Country people shall rise and concurre with them, when the Commanders of the Scottish Army shall thinke fit for the service, and shall receive Orders and directions from them, and in the 10. Article of that Treaty, if the Scottish Armie shall joyne with any other Forces in Ireland, The Generall of the Scottish Armie, shall onely Cede to the Kings Lieutenant, his deputy, or any other who shall have the chiefe government of that Kingdome, derived from the Crowne of England, and otherwise, the Generall of the Scottish Armie is to precede, and have the Command of all others: and when this Treaty was made, there was no other meane left for preserving that Kingdome from utter ruine, but to joyne with the Scottish and British Forces under one Command for opposing the Cessation. And it is to be considered, that whereas by the which Article of the Treaty 6. of August, the prosecution of the Warre of Ireland by the Scottish Armie, is left to the judgement of the Commanders of the Scottish Army, as they shall think most expedient for the honour of the King, and Crowne of England, and only in the case of conjunction with the Kings Lieutenant, or Deputy by authority from the Crowne of England, they are to receive instructions from them in an honourable way, to whom he is onely to Cede, and to precede all others. By this new Treaty, the Commanders of the Scottish Army, subject themselves to the orders and directions of a Committe of both Kingdomes, whereby their power is so farre diminished and limited which it was not before. Also, this is onely to continue during the warre, and is at an end, how soone
a peace is setled, or that the Scottish Armie shall be satisfied and dismissed, whereof we shall be heartily content. Whereas it is said, there is not a quid pro quo, that hath beene answered formerly, the stay of an Army after it hath been starved 16. monthes to save a Kingdome, is a quid pro quo, the Kingdome of Scotland, their sending supplyes to that Army, is a quid pro quo, and for that which is said, that in the 5. Article it is expressed, that in case the 50000. l. be not payd in February, the Army would not stay. And therefore, the condition of the money was the cause of their stay, and not the condition for the managing of the warre: It is no consequence, for it was expresly demanded by the Armie, and they would not stay so much, as to the first of February, without the conjunction of the British Forces, in manner aforesaid, because of the strength of the enemie, and therefore it was expreslie agreed upon in the 4. Article, and that their stay is mainlie pitched upon the payment of the money, the reason is cleare, because the meane of their subsistance is the Primarie condition, and necessarily presupposed, as the cause sine quo non, to which the conjunction of the Forces and managing of the warre is but secondary, and without it altogether unprofitable. And to conclude the whole debate, we desire it may be observed, that whereas by the Votes of the Houses it was appointed, that the Committee of both Houses should make it appeare to us, that the transactions at Edinburgh 28. November, 1643. was no Treaty: It was acknowledged in the debates on Saturday, the 28. of March last, that these transactions were an agreement between the Kingdomes, and a Treaty between the Kingdomes, but not a Treatie in such a sense as other Treaties that are obligatorie: and in the debates on Monday following, it was acknowledged to be obligatory in some, but not in all the Articles thereof. To which we make this answer. That the Commissioners of the Houses of Parliament, had a generall power to Treat, agree, and conclude, and in their Credentiall Letters given by the Houses to their Commissioners, there is no such distinction. 2. When the English Commissioners agree with the Estates of Scotland, they make no such distinction, nor is there any such distinction of diverse natures or senses in the Articles, as they are set down and agreed on, nor can they admit of any other interpretation then is expressed in the Articles themselves. 3. There is no such distinction made, when these Articles are ratified and confirmed by the Houses: Had any such distinction beene made known before the agreement, the time of the agreement, or the time of the confirmation (which without the clear expression of it, could never be apprehended by the Kingdome of Scotland) there had been some colour for such an objection: but the Articles being agreed on by Commissioners, having full and ample power, the agreement being granted upon demands of an Armie, left at
liberty to come away, and upon the offers and promises of the Houses, there being mutuall conditions between the two Kingdomes, and conditions being performed on Scotlands part, being ratified by the Houses, called by them, an Agreement, A Treatie, an Assurance, that upon which the Army might depend, and the Votes of the Houses delivered to us, as their consent to this Treatie. The Kingdome of Scotland being thereupon desired by the Houses to co-operate for the stay of the Army, and a Letter being written from the Houses to the Parliament of Scotland, acquainting them that they had ratified the severall Treaties between the Kingdomes, we having still demanded the performance of it, as a Treaty confirmed by the Houses, and no exception made, but still acknowledged as a Treaty till now. Upon these considerations wee are confident the honourable Houses will never deny it to bee a Treaty, wherein we are the more confirmed, that the Committee of both Houses, having taken a day to answere our arguments, and after that another, made no reply, wee having also at the close of the debate offered to their Lordships; That if they had any further scruples or doubts, we were ready and confident to give them satisfaction, and withall desired, that if any other papers were made use of, concerning this businesse then we had seen, they might be Communicated unto us, that nothing might be wanting which might give the honourable Houses full satisfaction.
